concepts.concept_name: Need for standard units of measurement
SI units of length, mass, and time
Measuring length using rulers and measuring tapes
Measuring mass using balance and weighing scale
Measuring time using clocks and stopwatches

in_scope: Need for measurement in daily life
Using rulers and measuring tapes correctly
out_of_scope: Vernier calipers and screw gauge - Introduced in Class 8
Volume measurement in detail - Covered in Class 7
Density calculations - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Definition of motion and rest
Types of motion: linear, circular, rotational, oscillatory, random
Speed and its measurement
Distance and time relationship

in_scope: Motion: change in position with respect to time
Linear motion: movement in a straight line
Circular motion: movement in a circle
Rotational motion: spinning around an axis
Oscillatory motion: to and fro movement
out_of_scope: Velocity and acceleration - Introduced in Class 8
Equations of motion - Introduced in Class 9
Graphical representation of motion - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Definition of force as push or pull
Effects of force: change in motion, shape, direction
Types of forces: muscular, frictional, gravitational, magnetic
Contact and non-contact forces

in_scope: Force can start, stop, or change direction of motion
Force can change shape of objects
Muscular force: force exerted by muscles
Frictional force: opposes motion between surfaces
Gravitational force: pulls objects toward Earth
Magnetic force: attraction or repulsion by magnets
Non-contact forces: act at a distance
out_of_scope: Newton's laws of motion - Introduced in Class 9
Force calculations (F=ma) - Introduced in Class 8
Pressure concept - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Sources of light: natural and artificial
Transparent, translucent, and opaque objects
Formation of shadows
Reflection of light by plane mirrors
Characteristics of images in plane mirrors

in_scope: Artificial sources: bulbs, candles, tube lights
Shadow formation requires light source, opaque object, screen
Image: same size, laterally inverted, virtual
out_of_scope: Laws of reflection - Introduced in Class 7
Spherical mirrors - Introduced in Class 8
Refraction of light - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Sound is produced by vibrating objects
Sound requires a medium to travel
Sound travels through solids, liquids, and gases
Loudness and pitch of sound

in_scope: Vibrating objects: vocal cords, strings, membranes
Sound needs a medium to travel
Sound travels through air, water, wood, metal
Speed of sound varies in different media
Loudness: how loud or soft a sound is
Pitch: how high or low a sound is
out_of_scope: Frequency and wavelength - Introduced in Class 8
Speed of sound calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Echo and reverberation - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Electric circuit components: cell, wire, bulb, switch
Open and closed circuits
Conductors and insulators
Electric symbols and circuit diagrams

in_scope: Electric bulb: converts electricity to light
Closed circuit: complete path for current
Open circuit: broken path, no current flow
Insulators: do not allow electricity to pass (plastic, rubber)
out_of_scope: Electric current and voltage - Introduced in Class 7
Ohm's law - Introduced in Class 9
Series and parallel circuits calculation - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Properties of magnets
Magnetic and non-magnetic materials
Poles of a magnet and their interaction
Uses of magnets in daily life

in_scope: Magnets have two poles: north and south
Like poles repel, unlike poles attract
Magnetic materials: iron, cobalt, nickel, steel
Non-magnetic materials: wood, plastic, copper, aluminum
Uses: compass, refrigerator doors, speakers, motors
out_of_scope: Magnetic field lines - Introduced in Class 7
Electromagnets - Introduced in Class 8
Earth's magnetism in detail - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Sources of heat
Difference between heat and temperature
Measuring temperature using thermometers
Transfer of heat: conduction, convection, radiation
Conductors and insulators of heat

in_scope: Heat: form of energy that flows from hot to cold
Temperature: measure of hotness or coldness
Convection: heat transfer through liquids and gases
out_of_scope: Thermal expansion calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Specific heat capacity - Introduced in Class 9
Latent heat - Introduced in Class 8
